answers.answer: Dear P. P.All the options you have mentioned are appropriate to consider for your mother.  It is likely that the valve replacement should she be a candidate would be the potentially best option.  Very often valves in the older patients may not be amenable to repair.  Valvuloplasty is a temporizing measure and will not have long term benefits.If your mother has otherwise been functional and her other medical conditions are under good control, surgical therapy should be considered.  I am unable to give you risks and benefits  per se but these should be discussed with your cardiologist and/or cardiovascular surgeon.I hope this has been useful. I wish you the best of luck. Feel free to write back.Information provided here is for general purposes only. Specific questions should be addressed to your owndoctor. If you would like to make an appointment at the Cleveland Clinic Heart Center, please call1-800-CCF-CARE or inquire online by using the Heart Center website at www.ccf.org/heartcenter. The HeartCenter website contains a directory of the cardiology staff that can be used to select the physician best suited toaddress your cardiac problem.

question: My mother, who is 75 years old, is in the hospital after an episode of passing out.  She was brought to the Emergency Room in atrial fibrillation, shortness of breath, and rapid pulse.  She has just been diagnosed (by Echocardiogram) with Mitral Valve Stenosis.  She has had insulin-dependent diabetes for about 20 years, which she manages poorly.  This has caused her eyesight to deteriorate markedly, and has resulted in her having to have part of her right great toe amputated.  She also has significantly reduced kidney function.  She has had Congestive Heart Failure for at least 10 years, which is usually under control with medications, but about once a year she will have an episode of shortness of breath and fluid buildup in her lungs, for which she has needed brief hospitalization.Her current medications are as follows:Methadone orally twice daily(for chronic back pain--she had been on Vicodin)60 units Novulin Insulin each morning25mg Lanoxin2 tablets of Tenormin twice a day.6mg Colchacine twice a day1 Xyloprym each morning40 mg. Lasix twice a dayOver the counter Calcium and Vitamin E supplementsShe has allergies to Penecillin and Sulfa-based drugs.She has also been started on Coumadin therapy in the hospital.I understand that her treatment options are as follows:a)  Treat with medications (i.e. Coumadin)b)  Have a balloon vulvoplastyc)  Valve repaird)  Valve replacement, either with a pig's valve or artificial valveMy questions are:Are the above options correct, and are they all of the options available?  Also, I would like to know, given my mother's medical history, your opinion of the risks, benefits, and long-term survivability of the various therapies/proced
title: Mitral Valve Stenosis
